awd_titl_txt: Conference: Conference: Functional Logic of Neural circuits: diamonds in the rough (2024)
awd_abstract_narration:
Natural behavior is the result of complex interactions between neurons, between neurons and the body, and between the body and the environment.  Understanding the neural circuits underpinning animal behavior, therefore, involves unravelling this web of interactions and has captured the imagination and efforts of biologists, physicists, mathematicians, engineers, and artificial intelligence researchers alike. This award provides funding for researchers in these various disciplines to come together and find common direction, exchange ideas and insights, and create new collaborations.

The organizers will lead a workshop on the Functional Logic of Neural Circuits. The workshop will take place in Puerto Rico in February 2024.  The goal of the workshop is to create a highly interactive environment that fosters maximum information exchange amongst a diverse set of researchers from experimental, computational, and theoretical neuroscience, structural and functional connectomics, genomics, and artificial intelligence.  To accomplish this goal, the workshop includes several planned activities including chalk talks, panel discussions, and random group breakouts. The workshop will result in a comprehensive summary that will be widely disseminated for the purpose of fostering new community efforts around this challenging scientific problem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The emerging Neuroscience field of Connectomics studies the complex web of connections among brain neurons, and is transforming our understanding of how the brain works. Additionally, whole brain neural wiring diagrams called connectomes are being analzed in the context of other rich datasets on brain neural activity and behavior, which is further accelerating the pace of discovery. This requires that scientists from different backgrounds collaborate and find new ways to interpret and integrate this wealth of information. The workshop "Functional Logic of Neural Circuits: Diamonds in the Rough" brought together experts from different fields to explore these challenges. Participants aimed to generate new ideas and insights into how the nervous system funtions, thus paving the way for future research directions. This collaborative approach is crucial for translating complex data into meaningful knowledge about how nervous systems produce behavior, in normal and diseased brains.


The workshop was held in San Juan, Puerto Rico from February 21 to 23, 2024 and featured a combination of in-person and remote participation, including 23 attendees on-site and 10 joining virtually. Over three days, attendees engaged in presentations and discussions that focussed on the latest challenges in neural circuits research. Highlights included discussions on the interaction between the nervous system, body, and environment, advances in connectomics, the emergence of neural activity in the developing brain, and roles for artificial intelligence in neural circuits research. A key feature of the workshop was the emphasis on collaborative work, with participants forming workgroups to address shared challenges and propose innovative solutions. The workshop not only fostered new collaborations but also provided a platform for participants, including early-career researchers who shared their work and insights. At the conclusion of the workshop, many attendees participated in a symposium with neuroscience researchers and students in Puerto Rico, further enriching the dialogue around these critical topics. The outcomes of this workshop are expected to lead to significant advancements in our understanding of neural circuits, with collaborative projects poised to generate impactful publications in 2025.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Andrew M Seeds
